string.text: The rules of the tournament are standard across Japan. We match the fighters up by drawing lots. Sometimes youre part of a team, and sometimes you fight by yourself.

As well you might! Theyre a grand old custom thats now spread all over Japan. Back in the old days, theyd give a hundred condemned criminals swords and have them slash at each other until the sands were drenched in blood![if:convo_merry]
The rules of the tournament are standard across Japan. We match the fighters up by drawing lots. Sometimes youre part of a team, and sometimes you fight by yourself.
For all the coin aboard the Black Ships \n For all the tribute of the Great Ming \n For all the jade of Yunnans hills...

Ah, no. Slavers are rare these days. It used to be that, when the clans made war upon each other, the defeated were usually taken as slaves. That helped pay for the war, you see! But today, for better or for worse, that is not practical. With the scale of wars Japan has found itself in, there are far too many opportunities for captives to escape. But that does not mean that war cannot be profitable! Indeed it still can!
Many captives are still taken, and their families will pay to have them back. Men such as I criss-cross Japan, acquiring prisoners, and contacting their kin for a suitable ransom.

Oh, I suppose I could sell them to the pirates of Ryukyu, to row their bunes, although even in Ryukyu they prefer free oarsmen these days... But it rarely comes to that. Youd be surprised what sorts of treasures a peasant can dig out of his cowshed or wheedle out of his cousins!

It varies. I fancy that I have a fine eye for assessing a ransom. There are a dozen little things about a man that will tell you whether he goes to bed hungry, or spices his meat with pepper and cloves. The real money of course is in the aristocracy, and if you ever want to do my job youll want to learn about every landowning family or tribal chief in Japan, their estates, their offspring both lawful and bastard, and, of course, their credit with the merchants.
Of course. Im welcome in every court in Japan. Theres not many who can say that! So always be sure to keep a pot of mon buried somewhere, and a loyal servant who can find it in a hurry.
Monkey sings up in the pine. I stole the daimyos favorite wine.{newline}Crow replies with feathered grin, That lord of Kai is drunk again.
Mijosi rule Osaka fair. But daggers flash within the lair.{newline}One by one their lights go out. And whispers take the halls with doubt.
Nobunaga always schemes. Talks of guns and foreign dreams.{newline}Builds a castle in a day, then burns ten temples on the way.
Ieyasu sits, both calm and still. Waiting as the rice fields fill.{newline}Speaks but once, and none deny. A turtles patience wins the sky.
Chosokabe grows his rice. And counts his sons like clans of mice.{newline}The island sleeps, but not for long. He teaches peasants to be strong.
The priest of Enryaku rang his bell. To scare off demons back to hell.{newline}But the demon laughed and stayed the night. Said ‘Your prayer was weak, now pass the rice.
Saburo Saburo fought a boar. Drove it screaming to the floor.{newline}Not with blade or sharpened spear. But garlic breath and gourd of beer.
Growing up in the city, you spent most of your time...
Like all village children you worked from a young age. You spend your time...
As a youngster growing up in Japan, war was never too far away. You...

You spent your adolescence days training your sword skills together with other kids. Whether it was with real blades or improvised ones, in actual practice or imaginary duels, you improved your slashes and parries with no need to roll around.

You were sent to study with a scholar to deepen your mathematical knowledge and learn the basics of physics. Day after day, you learned the secrets of calculation and engineering, giving you the skills to draw your first projects and draft detailed records.

You accompanied a merchant as his apprentice, learning his trade and acquiring the skills of a good salesman. After an adolescence spent between markets and warehouses, you learnt the secrets of bargaining and commerce.

You spent your adolescence working in a forge as the apprentice of a master swordsmith, learning the secrets of forge and blade in equal measure. By the end of your apprenticeship, you were able to forge a sword discreetly on your own, and why not, even swing it around.

You were sent to work as a young servant at the estate of a rich landowner from the city. Gradually progressing from menial tasks to more complex ones, you eventually became a sort of administrator of the estate, managing its stocks and liaising with the guests of your master. Once your service with the wealthy landlord was over, you were a young adult able to administer a fortune and deal with the citys high society.

You spent your adolescence on the streets of the city, often getting into trouble and growing closer and closer to the local underworld, eventually becoming a member of a gang of young criminals. After years in this environment, you have learned all the secrets of commiting crimes and getting out of the resulting trouble.

As a kid you went almost every day to train with a jizamurai who stayed in your village for a few years and who seemed to like you enough to teach you how to fight for free. When your mentor finally left the village by the time you had become a young adult, you were a discreet and robust fighter.

You spent your adolescence working in a forge as the apprentice of a blacksmith, being educated in the production of tools for the fields and the other activities in the village. By the end of your apprenticeship, you had become yourself a skilled blacksmith capable of crafting and handling several tools

Your father was the trusted retainer of a jito, a minor lord in charge of a manor or estate. After several years of loyal service as bodyguard and enforcer, he was raised to the rank of samurai and with that he was granted the right to carry a sword and was provided with a mount and armour to accompany his master.

Your family thrived in the trade of sake. From their house in one of the largest towns of Japan they ran several breweries and sold their products to customers throughout the Country. Despite the wealth they accumulated over the years and the influence that it carried, their less than friendly practices with their competitors stained their reputation with mistrust and contempt from most.

Your father was a humble but skilled swordsmith who through his physical strength and mastery of his art was able to transform raw metal into sharp blades, making him well known in his domain for the quality of his creations. Even as a child, by helping him in the forge, you were able to absorb some of his craftmanship and harden your body.

A disgraced samurai who had lost his master, your father wandered the countryside as a ronin in search of opportunities and trouble. Being unable to avenge his fallen master and recover his previous standing, he was forced to accept employment as a mercenary or cutthroat to survive. Despite originally hailing from a higher class, your fathers demotion and turbulent history are still a shame to wash away from your family.

A soldier for hire, your father travelled around the country looking for a new employer, hoping his next job would pay enough and not cost him his life. Only after many bloody battles and scarred wounds he retired, the money he had saved being enough to allow him to settle down in the countryside for a simple but comfortable life.

Your father was the head of a flourishing tea farm, cultivating the delicate leaves with expertise and dedication the ancient traditions. While as head of the farm your father was entitled to a large share of the profits, he was still a farmer and never shied away from manual labour, and you too, spending your childhood among the tea bushes, grew very familiar with farm tools and herbs.

Living on the outskirts of his village, your father was a skilled hunter, well-versed in tracking and chasing his prey through the woods and mountains. and taking it down with a swift stroke of his bow. Even if the rewards of his labour were barely enough for a humble life in the countryside, your father passed on much of his knowledge to you.

Your parents were members of a renowned company of Noh actors. Together with their companions they travelled around the country enchanting audiences with their timeless performances and trying to make a living out of it. In spite of the obvious impossibility of settling down, your parents profession was the source of a deep knowledge of the different peoples of Japan and the skills needed to socialise with them.
as a servant to a wealthy family.

In your adolescence you were sent to a workshop as the apprentice of the local carpenter, learning the different ways of working wood and stone and how to use them for the construction of buildings essential to village life. To conclude your apprenticeship you lead the construction of the new village warehouse, proving your grasp of the fields of mathematics and engineering.

You spent the days of your adolescence working in the fields of a farm, in a job that was far from exciting but nevertheless necessary. The years spent working the land under the sun or transporting the harvest made you much stronger and more accustomed to handling farm tools.

As a kid you loved going into the woods and mountains with the hunters from the village, observing them and learning their skills. After several years benefiting from their guidance and teaching, you eventually became an integral part of the group as a skilled hunter yourself.
as a young actor in a noh troop.

As a teenager you chose to leave and join a company of noh actors, travelling and performing with them from town to town. After years of convincing representations and observing peoples reactions, you have become not just a skilled actor, but also someone who can convince and deceive others with only your words.
raised by monks in a temple.

Whether out of necessity or simple orphanhood, as a child you were placed in the care of a Buddhist monastery. The monks who raised you did not only instruct you in religious matters, but also in calligraphy, rhetoric, the knowledge of nature and the ways to use it to heal the body.

Thanks to your wealth or your social standing, you were able to join the army not as an ordinary soldier but as its commanders sandal-bearer, a sort of aide-de-camp and protégé. From the command tent or on the battlefield, you benefited from the mentoring of an experienced commander, learning first-hand what it means to lead soldiers in war.
Joined a gang of criminals in the city.
Sometimes to avoid being oppressed, it is better to join the oppressors. You joined a local gang, finding your safety in the strength of the pack while you learnt the ropes of the urban underworld.
Joined an army as a horseman.

When you enlisted the cavalry commander had you join his ranks, your riding skills had caught his attention and the fact your wealth allowed you to buy your own horse only strengthened his choice. Equipped as a light horseman, you often took part in scouting and skirmishing missions.
Became a messenger for a local army.

Your talent for memorization and sufficient riding skills caught the attention of the commander of your army, who entrusted you with the task of delivering his messages, partly written and partly memorised. Equipped with a fast horse and light armour, you rode through several battlefields often influencing the outcome with the information you transformed.
Fell in with a group of bandits.

To survive in the war-torn countryside, you chose to join a group of bandits to make a living at the expense of the very people who lived in the countryside. Killing and looting together with your gang, not too dissimilar from the plundering of passing armies, you became a ruthless raider.

If peace cannot be found on land, the seas are not entirely safe either. To escape the power struggles of the samurai, you chose to join a group of wokou pirates, attacking merchant ships careless enough to pass through pirate-controlled routes. Although it is easier to fight merchants than a samurai, ships are often defended by armed guards and you had your fair share of combat experience in addition to sailing.
Offered your service as an ashigaru spearman.

Large formations of ashigaru spearmen are the backbone of every army in warring Japan, but also its most expendable and easily accessible part. As a rank-and-file soldier you gained your combat experience alongside your comrades learning to defend yourself with the yari spear you were issued.
Helped build fortifications around the camp.

Not every member of an army is expected to fight in battle, logistics being a vital necessity for any military campaign and those who take care of them as important as fighters. Joining the rearguard, you assisted with setting up camp and building fortifications.
Joined an army as an archer.

As you enlisted in an army, you were noticed for your archery skills and were assigned to the ranks of bowmen supporting the soldiers engaged in melee combat from afar. Through constant training and battle experience, you became a dependable member of the unit, providing vital support with your yumi bow and arrows.

As the newest member of the army you had joined, you were sent forward with almost minimal if any equipment to scout the terrain ahead of the marching troops. As an increasingly skillful and experienced scout, you ventured into unknown territories, mapping enemy positions and gathering crucial intelligence that frequently proved decisive for the success of your armys strategies.
Joined a temple as a monk

You managed to avoid war in your youth by joining a temple. Temples are not only a spiritual place, but an educative one. As a monk you spent many nights studying philosophy, poetry, law, war, and more. Your studies have granted you a unique insight into the art of war and administration.

You were part of the garrison of a castle-town that was besieged by an enemy army. As one of the many defenders you were called to secure the defensive positions until the enemies were finally repulsed and lifted the siege.
You do not have enough ships to carry all your troops.
You do not have enough ships to carry all your troops. You have ships in production. Open the naval management screen to see them.
You do not have enough gold to take the ferry.
You do not have enough gold to take the ferry.
You do not have enough gold to take the ferry.
You do not have enough gold to take the ferry.
You do not have enough gold to take the ferry.
You do not have enough gold to take the ferry.
Your men have returned with loot.
{HIDEOUT_DESCRIPTION}. Your men have returned with loot.
The Fall of the Triple Alliance

Oda Nobunaga has successfully marched on Kioto and installed Ashikaga Yoshiaki as the new Shogun of Japan. Although this was done with the intention of strengthening the Ashikaga Shogunate, Yoshiaki will soon realize he is another puppet shogun like Yoshihide before him. For now, the central authority of the Shogun remains weak.
The Honjo rebellion has been crushed by the Uesugi. All rebel clans have been forced to recognize the authority of the Uesugi clan, and have been brought back into the fold.
The Kimotsuki rebellion has been crushed by the Shimazu. The Kimotsuki have been forced to swear loyalty to the Shimazu, ending their bid for independence.

The fragile triple alliance between the Takeda, Hojo, and Imagawa clans has finally collapsed. The Takeda have invaded the Suruga Province of the Imagawa with the help of the Tokugawa, but the Uesugi has agreed to come to their aid. Now the Takeda face a two front war with minimal allies, which will decide the fate of the Chubu region.

Ashikaga Yoshiaki, with the aid of Oda Nobunaga, has declared themselves the rightful Shogun of Japan. The armies of the Oda clan march on Kioto. If they manage to wipe out any resistance in their way, Yoshiaki will become the new Shogun of Japan.
The Honjo rebellion has managed to defeat the Uesugi, and carve for themselves a new kingdom. The Uesugi are forced to accept their independence.
The Kimotsuki rebellion has managed to defeat the Shimazu, and carve for themselves a new kingdom. The Shimazu are forced to accept their independence.
5% of the village income is paid to the ruler clan as tax{newline}5% less village income for clans
reevaluating taxes for farms and fields
Conduct surveys to evaluate taxes for farms and fields by considering not only their size but also the quality of their harvests.
monopolizing control of markets to a single merchant

Choosing a single merchant to lead over the rest of the domains merchants means they will have supervision over market peddlers, authority to collect taxes from merchants, and sole control over market affairs. This brings in more income through taxes at the cost of certain maketplace freedoms.
allowing the ruler to appoint magistrates

Assigning magistrates, called Daikan, to solve disputes and render verdicts on crimes will help cut down on gang activity and lawlessness. Unfortunately, this is often greatly resented by affected communities.
Ruler clan gains 100 denars per day for each town in the domain{newline}Settlement loyalty is decreased by 1 per day
Currency shortages can be allieviated by allowing imported coins and wartime minted coins to have monetary value. The people will likely be reluctant to accept these new currencies.
collecting dues from ships at port
Ships entering ports or harbors must pay taxes according to their size, amount, and type of cargo they are carrying.
Towns held by the ruler clan gain 1 Loyalty and 1 Prosperity per day{newline}Towns held by non-ruler clans lose 0.3 Loyalty per day
Establish an economic policy that denies certain merchants privileges in towns and ports, but gives certain guarantees and tax exemptions for businesses.

The influence cost of creating an army is reduced by 30% for the ruler{newline}Armies led by the ruler earn cohesion at 30% less cost{newline}Armies led by non-ruler nobles cost 10% more influence to create
In response to the need for a stronger and more organized military, lesser lords could be added to the ranks of armies in the field to bolster their concentration of power.
Rulers party size is increased by 60{newline}Non-ruling clans lose 0.2 influence per day.
Talented warriors excelling in martial arts are recruited into the umamawari, an organized escort for the ruler.
Ruler gains 5% tax from all settlements{newline}Towns lose 1 prosperity per day{newline}The influence cost of declaring war is doubled for the ruler clan
letting the ruler collect extra taxes in wartime
Wartime taxes, called yasen, can be collected from temples, shrines, and merchants. Doing so will increase tax gain at the cost of town prosperity and more influence needed to declare war.
For kingdom decisions, the influence cost of the ruler overriding the popular decision outcome is reduced by 20%

The ruler may consider the opinions of those lower in the hierarchy to suppress discontent but the final decision will remain the rulers alone. Establishing this will allow the ruler greater authority when overriding certain decisions.
Tier 3+ clans gain 0.5 influence per day, influence cost of inviting lower tier clans to army are increased by 10%
Samurai clans can be incorporated into the imperial court hierarchy, further separating the power between the ranks of each clan.
Tier 5+ clans gain 0.5 influence per day, influence cost of inviting lower tier clans to army are increased by 20%
Military achievements grant 20% more influence{newline}Troop wages are increased by 10%
granting awards for deeds in the field
Samurai who make strides on the battlefield can be rewarded for their service. These can include fiefdoms and certificates of gratitude, bringing honor to their clan and families.
Issuance of Certificates and Distribution of Territories
Domains can specify strict and formal laws of inheritance making it more difficult to revoke land.
Villages grant 0.2 influence per day to the owner clan{newline}Towns gain 1 security but lose 1 militia per day
issuing orders for peasants to return to their land

By fleeing villages, peasants can escape the path of war at the risk of leaving the area abandoned. Doing so can cause hardships for those left behind and those of neighboring regions, who must now do the work of those who fled. Peasants can be ordered to return, with exemptions of burden for abiding and severe punishments for refusing.
Decree of Return to The Village
Tier 5+ clans lose 1 influence per day and the party size of their leaders is increased by 40
encouraging lords to have large armies
Nobles will now be expected to raise sizable retinues. Those who do so are referred to as yoriki.
Food production in towns and castles are increased by 2{newline}Town loyalty is decreased by 0.2
granting lords exclusive hunting rights to nearby fields
Nobles and other landowners will have exclusive rights to hunt in fields.
Trade tax paid to the town owner is increased by 3%{newline}Town prosperity is decreased by 0.2
allowing lords tolls on trade routes running through their holdings
Landowners as well as holders of sea routes will be granted the right to collect tolls on commerce.
Armies led by Tier 5+ nobles require 10% less influence{newline}Influence of the ruler clan is reduced by 1 per day
granting prestigious nobles the right to summon large armies
The most prestigious samurai clans are preferred when entrusting lords with armies.
Each notable yields 0.1 influence per day to the settlements owner clan{newline}Tax from fortifications 5% decreased
allowing the ruler to resolve disagreements

Long-standing disputes over land boundaries, water rights, mountain rights, or any other disagreements between parties can be exhaustive. By allowing the ruler final judgment, these issues can be resolved quickly.

+0.5 Loyalty per day to settlements that have the same culture as their owner clan{newline}Settlement militia production is increased by 1{newline}-0.5 Loyalty per day to settlements with a different culture than its owner clan
offering positions of power to relatives
Dominion can be concentrated within the domain by arranging powerful positions in the territory with people closely related to the ruling clan.
Settlement loyalty is increased by 2 per day{newline}Settlement production is reduced by 5%

Creditors and financiers can be commanded to release those with debt, providing relief to impoverished fiefdoms. Doing so will help the livelihood of those in need but will be detrimental to parts of the domains economy.
Town taxes paid to the ruler are reduced by 5%{newline}Town loyalty is increased by 1 per day

Establishes a lawsuit suggestion box to guarantee the right of a court trial for peasants. Doing this will prevent accusations of unjustness by local officials and prevent disputes among residents from escalating into violence.
Settlement loyalty is increased by 0.5 per day{newline}Daily hearth production at villages decreases by 0.25 per day

Local lords can grant temples, shrines, samurai, and wealthy peasants the right to manage the forests on behalf of the community. Allowing this would promote resource management, prevent competition for timber, and avert the destruction of mountainous areas.
All clans whose leader has high Charm gain 1 influence per day{newline}All clans whose leader has low Charm lose 1 influence per day
inviting lords to participate in cultural activities

Promotes cultural activites such as tea ceremony, Renga poetry, Noh drama, etc., and stimulate exchanges between feudal lords. This brought together feudal lords, court nobles, and merchants to increase their power, but it was not good for those who were considered uncultured.
Settlement loyalty is increased by 0.5 per day{newline}Settlement security is decreased by 0.2 per day{newline}Clans lose 1 influence per day

Villages can be given more autonomy, becoming more cohesive by establishing village codes and laws. This can lead to unchecked power amongst the village leadership, reducing the influence of lords, which can lead to conflicts between the two parties.
Daily militia production is increased by 1{newline}Recruits replenish 20% faster{newline}Tax income in settlements are reduced by 10%

Orders can be issued to the population to take up arms and prepare for war, no matter if they are a peasant, merchant, or an artisan. They may not be the best of forces, but they are better than nothing.
Settlement security is increased by 1 per day{newline}Settlement militia production is decreased by 1 per day
confiscating swords from commoners across the domain

Sending troops throughout the realm to confiscate weapons will help to decrease the chance of successful rebellions. This also divides the classes of commoners and nobility even further by allowing samurai to keep their armaments, but not peasants.

Settlement security is increased by 1 per day{newline}Settlement loyalty is increased by 1 per day{newline}Settlement prosperity is decreased by 1 per day{newline}Village hearths are decreased by .5 per day

Establishing a census for villages and expelling new residents. Bandits and troublesome ronin will have difficulties taking root in the area. It will severely limit the growth of villages but will lower the chances of banditry in the area.
Settlement prosperity is increased by .5 per day{newline}Settlement loyalty is decreased by .5 per day{newline}Clans lose 1 influence per day
heeding the counsel of foreign advisors

Heeding the counsel of foreign advisors will open up new ideas and relations with external powers. This will help with foreign relations and trade but nobles may distrust the spread of outside influence.

Utilizing family as a bargaining tool is an effective way to solidify the relations between factions and ensure that treatises are obeyed. Hostages will dramatically assist in matters of diplomacy but will cause a loss to the factions influence.

The influence cost of recruiting lords into an army is reduced by 30%{newline}Recruitment availability of units from religious sites increased by 1{newline}Workshop production is reduced by 15%{newline}Clans lose 1 influence per day

With religious influence reaching far across the lands, more fanatical followers will emerge. Fostering this kind of religious fervor will help to encourage religious leaders to donate more men to fight on behalf of lords whose beliefs align with their own.
Settlement taxes paid to the ruler are reduced by 5%{newline}Ships are 25% cheaper and build 25% faster

Opportunities in trade with distant regions and the need to bolster the quality of naval vessels mean that the priority of high-quality resources should rest with shipbuilders. The factions territory will see cheaper and faster ships to craft, as well as an increase in growth to port cities, at the cost of income from villages.
donating lands for use by religious sects
Lords can donate some of their territory to religious sects. Territories donated this way are difficult to take away, even for rulers.

Settlement prosperity increases by 2 per day{newline}Clans lose 1 influence per day{newline}Tax income in settlements are increased by 15%{newline}Settlement loyalty is decreased by 1 per day{newline}Settlement Security is decreased by 1 per day{newline}Each notable yields -.25 influence per day to the settlements owner clan{newline}Access to Naval Cannons during sieges

Opening local markets to exotic imports will introduce unique wares, technology, and culture to the region. Even though new export and import opportunities will arise, some notables and merchants may harbor disdain for the competition to domestic trade.
Settlement prosperity decreases by 2 per day{newline}Tax income in settlements are decreased by 5%{newline}Allows access to Ammo Caches during offensive sieges

To prevent supply complications during siege operations, towns will need to give up some of their supplies intended for the markets. Doing so will allow for supplies to be prioritized for offensive sieges, but will also cause negative impacts to prosperity in towns.
You cannot wait on the water.
You should not be able to see this. If you do, make a bug report at tag Foozle, make sure to describe what you are currently doing!
You should not be able to see this. If you do, make a bug report at tag Foozle, make sure to describe what you are currently doing!
You cannot abandon your lord while wounded
You are too wounded to participate in this battle.
Since this battle is so lopsided, you think you can wait in the back of the battle line. You will not receive xp for this battle if you choose this option.
Since this battle is so lopsided, you think you can wait in the back of the battle line. You will not receive xp for this battle if you choose this option.
Your lord expects you to participate in this battle.
The battlefield has been picked clean
You demanded all of {QUEST_GIVER.LINK}s sons goods. The swords are yours, but you can no longer complete {QUEST_GIVER.LINK}s task, as you have stolen their entire shipment.
Wait. I dont want to fight, Im leaving.
Search for {HERO.LINK}s heirloom and bring it back to him
How dare you? How about you run {DISTANCE} units, just for fun.
The artisan pointed out the rough position to where the bandits might be, hunt them down
Glorious! The congregation will be forever grateful! We will pray for your safe and swift return !Vá com Deus!
Hail Sir! What brings you to me
I am looking for a certain someones belonging he said that he was robbed around here so the robbers surely had to try to sell it quickly
Is that true? Well, that is interesting. Just some days ago a group of ragged looking men came around the market to try to sell off what seemed a pretty valuable item
Really? Did you see where did they take off to?

I did not really wanted to get into any trouble so I did not look, BUT theres rumors of a certain bandit hideout nearby if you think those are your guys you can take your chances and look for it (Quest END)
So, did you recover my heirloom?
Yes I did. Now give me my reward
Ok Great. Now leave. Heres your reward
Actually no, I wont give it to you unless you pay me well
What?!!! You SNAKE here take it and never come back
You know what, why shouldnt I keep it?
What?!!! You THIEF get out of here right now
We have run into some trouble trying to create a place of worship for the newly converted.Perhaps you might be willing to assist us ?
Yeah sure padre, tell me what to do!

The people of this land have been asking for a new church; one to instil the blessings of The Lord on the faithful and those who have yet to accept Christ into their hearts.A few men have been hired to help build this new place of worship, however, their hands are idle; a shipment of building materials destined for us never arrived.I have heard of bandits and thieves making off with folks property, but to steal from The Lord, how terrible. I pray that you might help us retrieve what we have lost.
Dont worry, we will bring the name of god to all these lands
This book will not take you long to read
This book will take you a little while to read
This book will take you some time to read
Someone else is reading this book
You no longer have this book
You have already read this book
You need {XP} xp to level up
This is the number of troops your navy can transport. You need more troop capacity than your total party size to set sail.
This is the amount of cargo your navy can transport. You need more cargo capacity than your total inventory weight to set sail.
This is the limit of ships you can have in your fleet. To increase this limit, increase your renown level.
Ships in this left side will be scuttled and destroyed.
This is the total daily upkeep of your fleet.

A scroll filled with techniques and diagrams of swordsmanship in the Kage-ryū style. Developed in 1438 by Aisu Hisatada, Kage-ryū has established itself as one of the three major origins for the evolution of sword based-martial arts.
A scroll detailing the techniques of the Shintō-ryū style, a school of swordsmanship founded by Iizasa Ienao and now counted among the three main origins of the martial arts.
A scroll describing the Shinkage-ryū style swordsmanship style, a school established by Kamiizumi Nobutsuna as a derivative of the Kage-ryū style.
This scroll summarises the swordsmanship techniques of the Ten-ryū style, a martial arts school that also includes polearms, throwing and jūjutsu.
A scroll that describes the techniques of the Toda-ryū style of swordsmanship, a school founded by Itō Kagehisa after visiting Kanemaki Michimune, a master of the Nakajo-ryū style
This scroll contains the teachings of Marume Nagayoshi, a disciple of the Shintō-ryū style and founder of the Marumeshinkage-ryū school of swordsmanship.
A scroll depicting the techniques of Hōzōin-ryū school, a spear martial arts specialised in the use of the Jumonji sickle spear to enable diverse offensive and defensive techniques.
A book written by Ogasawara Mochinaga, master of archery for Shogun Ashikaga Yoshinori, that explains how to handle the bow and what to do when it is broken.
This book contains the secret archery techniques of the Takeda Clan, passed down for generations and written down by Takeda Motonobu, head of a junior branch of the clan.
This book describes the horseriding technique of the Ōtsubo-ryū school, one of the classical schools of horsemanship that counts the Ashikaga Shoguns among its practitioners.
This scroll details the medicinal method of horse breeding and contains a depiction of the patron god of horse doctors as well as medicinal herbs used as horse medicine.

This scroll contains the teachings of the Anzai-ryū school of horse medicine and describes the relationship between esoteric philosophy and horse diseases, including the methods and effects of treatment with acupuncture.
This book describes the secrets of horse treatment written by Kuwashima Hirotsuna and provides details on the parts of the horses body and various methods of moxibustion treatment.
A book containing the teachings of Hachijō Fusashige, founder of the Hachijo-ryu school of horsemanship.
This book by Ogasawara Mochinaga, master of archery for Shogun Ashikaga Yoshinori, describes the manners and techniques of the Yabusame mounted archery.
This book by Ogasawara Motonaga, son of Mochinaga master of archery for the Ashikaga Shogunate, details the manners and techniques of the Kasagake mounted archery.
This book by Ogasawara Mochinaga, master of archery for Shogun Ashikaga Yoshinori, describes the manners and techniques of the Inuoumono mounted archery.
This scroll contains a secret gunpowder recipe, originally sent by Ōtomo Sōrin, and describes the method of preparation, precautions and proportions of ingredients.
This scroll describes the production of gunpowder techniques of the Tsuda-ryū school of artillery.
This scroll explains how to produce gun ammunition and more than 30 different types of balls, including balls made by connecting several balls with a wire and hollow balls.
A book describing the art of gunnery. Written by Karaudo Chikahiro, a firearm instructor for the Jimbo clan.

A set of scrolls describing the art of gunnery of the Kisiŭada-ryū school of gunnery, written by Josida Morisada. The book details proper firing techniques and gunpowder recipes. The scroll also includes many descriptions from a spiritual perspective, linking guns with esoteric Buddhism and the role of guns in expelling evil demons
A scroll containing over three decades of esoteric iconography and scriptures, assembled by Kintaibō Kakuzen. Contains over one hundred volumes and is one of the largest collections of its kind.

A scroll containing the different scholastic and oral traditions from various schools of esoteric Buddhism, organized into two hundred twenty-eight volumes. Organized by Gokurakubō Jōchō, taking over thirty years to compile.

A scroll containing the oral traditions, events, and manners from various schools of esoteric Buddhism. Organized by Sōkushoin Koshu, a learned monk of the Tendaj sect, who ascended Mount Hiei to study the unique sects of Buddhism.
A book of scrolls compiling rituals and doctrines related to mountain ascetic practices of Shugendo. Written by Akyubou Sokuden, a mountain ascetic from Mount Nikko.
A book of letters testifying to the transmission of ritual doctrine in Shugendo. Written by Akyubou Sokuden, a mountain ascetic from Mount Nikko.

Five volumes authored by, Ucunomija Sadamune,an officer in charge of managing the Katana of the Shogun Ashikaga Yoshimitsu. He categorized katana by period and presented a genealogy of katana smiths, as well as famous swords and their measurements.
A scroll containing a list of names of katana smiths by region. Includes each smiths inscriptions, weapon characteristics, anecdotes, and genealogical information.
A book finished by Saitō Toshimasa, started by his father, that covers around eight hundred forty Katana. Includes Katana from Awataguchi, Soshu, Chugoku-Shikoku, Hokuriku, Bizen-Bicchu, and Kyushu.
A book classifying katana smiths in different countries into five levels of evaluation and includes highlights of their blades, the date of their production, and examples of famous swords.
A book describing beliefs, origins, and history of the mountains of the Kinki region.

A book composed of experiences traveling from to Kamakura to Kioto in 1223. It is filled with phrases from old Chinese texts, poetry, Buddhist writings, as well as detailed descriptions of landscapes and landmarks.
A travelogue book composed of experiences on the way from Higashiyama, Kioto to Kamakura in 1242. It is filled with detailed descriptions of landscapes.

A collection of diary entries written by Abutsuni, consort of Fujiwara no Tameie. The entries focused on her travels from Kioto to Kamakura to appeal to the Kamakura Shogunate over a territorial dispute between her son and his half-brother.

A book, written by Shōgoin Dōkō, cataloging various materials of his travels on the Hokuriku Route. Includes various writings on the Ōshū region, multiple kinds of poems, legends, and writings on historical sites.
A book describing the life and culture of the warriors and provinces of Japan during the Muromachi period.
A collection of studies on Japans geography, customs, manners, and natural history. Written by Tei Shunkō who was sent to Japan to help in the suppression of Japanese Pirates.

A book detailing the relations between Korea and Japan, prepared by the Yi Dynasty diplomat Sin Suk-ju. It records the politics of Japan and Ryukyu, including history of diplomatic exchanges and reception of envoys.
A Japanese book on the military strategy established at the end of the Heian period. It was created as a supplementary military book to the writings of Sun Tzu.

This book is revered as one of Chinas major military strategy books, written by Sonshi. With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan. Utilized as a source for the writings of Takeda Shingen.
This book is revered as one of Chinas major military strategy books, written by Goshi. With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan.
Revered as one of Chinas major military strategy books. With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan.

A book on the theories of writing renga, written by the court noble Nijō Yoshimoto. It describes the history and rules of renga, the spirit of renga creation, attire, and how to organize renga meetings.

A book on the theories of writing Muromachi period renga, written by the renga master Sōgi. It describes the history of renga and the techniques of renga creation in a question-and-answer style, with examples.
This book is a collection of two thousand fifty-two renga poems, many written by samurai. Compiled by Ichijō Fuyuyoshi, Sanjōnishi Sanetaka, Sōgi and others.

Written by the monk Gene, this book is an assortment of diverse knowledge and education necessary for social life. The contents cover food, clothing, housing, occupations, territorial management, architecture, judiciary practices, professions, Buddhism, armor, culture, and recuperation.

Written by the nobleman Ichijō Kaneyoshi, this book is an assortment of miscellaneous information. Includes details on the social life of samurai and court nobles, horses, armor, blacksmithing, temples, famous painters, alcoholic beverages, landmarks, memorial services, teas, and much more.

Written by the nobleman Ichijō Kaneyoshi, this book is a compilation of Sinto and Buddhist Rituals, worship, processions, events, clothing, secret banquets, bad luck rites, imperial edicts, and other miscellaneous writings.

A collection of explanations into the manners and systems of the Muromachi Shogunates warrior class, including accounts of negotiations between court nobles and samurai. Authored by Ise Sadamachi, governor of Yamashiro Province.
A story describing the contrasts between the Taira and Minamoto, their subsequent battles and downfalls, and the human drama of the Heian Nobles.
An eight volume narrative on Minamoto no Yoshitsune and his followers.
A book detailing the accession of Emperor Go-Daigo. Includes the fall of the Kamakura Shogunate, and the new government and its collapse.
A Kamukura period biographical story based on the revenge of the Soga brothers in Fujino. Written in the style of a military history treatise.
A collection of four books on Confucious thought and five books on assorted poems, documents, rites, and other texts. It was possibly compiled in some way by Confucious himself.
An Encyclopaedia by Minamoto no Shitagō, containing about three thousand entries on his opinions of various matters.

A book of six hundred twenty articles filled with miscellaneous meanings of Japanese and Chinese words and phrases. Includes celestial phenomena, deities, countries, inner regions, geography, plants, grass, birds, beasts and insects, human affairs, the human body, Buddhism, treasures, clothing, musical instruments, miscellaneous items, food and drink, and more.
An Encyclopaedia of the Middle Ages, authored by Tōin Kinkata. Includes astronomy, geography, the divisions of court, literature, manners and customs, arts and crafts, religion, and taboos.
An Encyclopaedia by Tōroku Hanō with eighteen sections on society, seasonal events, quantities, language, human ethics, and more.
A scroll filled with an assortment of writings. Includes astronomy, geography, literature, divisions of court, customs, goods, arts and crafts, religion, and taboos.

A collection of thirty-one articles codifying the customary laws of maritime traders in the Seto Inland Sea. Includes regulations for ships, shipowners, sailors, maritime salvage, and nautical rituals.

Fifty-one articles comprising the codes of the Kamakura shogunate. Filled with diverse content including the duties of guardians and landowners and codifies unique samurai jurisprudence that differs from the traditional court law and manor law.

A commentary on the shogunates basic code of law, the Goseibaishikimoku, authored by Kiyohara no Nobukata. The contents contain quotes and explanations of the various theories of kōke law and discusses the blending of different kōke laws within samurai families.

Seventeen articles consisting of laws authored by Asakura Takakage, given to his heir Ujikage. The contents cover directives on the control of vassals, recruitment of personnel, strengthening of military power, emphasis on civil administration, fostering of territorial culture, strictness of justice, and vigilance against other domains.

An assorted set of laws written by Date Tanemune detailing a number of regulations on the governance of his territory. It is characterized by detailed provisions on criminal offenses such as murder and robbery, the broad recognition of landowners right to rule, and preferential treatment in the sale and purchase of land to craftsmen of arms and farming implements.

An article of law written by Imagawa Yoshimoto detailing a number of regulations on the governance of his territory. It provides stipulation on relations between lords and peasants, boundary disputes, responses in case of conflicts and banditry, restrictions on the sale and purchase of territory, provisions for the vassal system, non-interventionist rights, and inheritance and court procedures, and much more.

A set of laws written by Harunobu Takeda for the realms under the control of the Takeda Clan. A total of fifty-five articles, It stipulates the prohibition of private wars, the regulation of letters to other domains, the prohibition of sectarian disputes, and the prohibition of private alliances.

A set of laws written by Sagara Haruhiro for the realms under the control of the Sagara Clan. Includes stipulations on the sale and purchase of rice fields, master-servant relations, water access, fines for sheltering fugitives, and prohibits the Ikko sect. Prayers by anyone other than Buddhists, Sinto, or mountain dwelling priests are strictly prohibited.
A medical treatise compiled by Izumo no Hirosada from the Heian period, sporting a collection of medicinal herbs across the region.

A medical treatise compiled by Tamba Yasuyori, a doctor of acupuncture who served as court physician during the Heian period. It compiled into thirty volumes and consists of doctors ethics, general medical theory, therapies for various diseases, health and hygiene regimen, medical techniques and medical thought.

A leading medical treatise of the Kamakura period, compiled by the physician Kajiwara Shōzen. Kajiwara utilized his knowledge of medicine and references from the latest Chinese Medical texts of the period to assemble this set of volumes. Includes details on vast amount of illnesses and diagrams of internal organs.
Kajiwara Shōzens medical treatise written around 1313 and entirely in Chinese. Intended to transmit and preserve the art of medicine.

Ten volumes of Yū Sōritsus Ming dynasty medical texts reprinted and published by Asaino Sōzui, a merchant in Sakaj. Intended for en-masse sale, this collection is vital for spreading knowledge on a plethora of ailments.

A set of eight volumes on diseases and treatments by Manaze Dōzan. Contains information on diverse etiologies from ancient and modern Chinese sources and is vital for the cataloging and treating of numerous ailments across Japan.

A comprehensive collection of articles on the methods and procedures of castle building. Inside are detailed descriptions of the material, manpower, and techniques required of castles depending on their terrain and complexity.

Sou Kouryos completed collection of Shu military writings from the Song Dynasty. Each volume is filled with theories and doctrines on assorted military knowledge as well as descriptions of various siege engines and defensive equipment.

A postbattle location is the result of two armies clashing on the battlefield, leaving dead bodies on the ground. These bodies have armor and weapons that can be worth a fortune, but acquiring these items come at a serious risk. Scavengers will come from all over to plunder and loot the items, and you must compete with others to get as much as you can and get out before you are overwhelmed.{newline}{newline}A post battle can appear when two armies clash and a certain threshold of casualties take place, which is customizable in the options. When entering a post battle, you can select a small number of troops to accompany you. The number of troops you can bring in is dependent on the Roguery skill. Once inside, other looters will be there, collecting the loot of the previous battle. There are several loot piles on the map, which can be interacted with to loot the items. If you press “Alt”, you can see the location of all the loot piles. You can command your troops to loot the piles as well by telling them to do so as a command. Select the formation and left click on the pile you want them to loot.{newline}{newline}Enemy looters are focused on the loot and will only attack the player if they interrupt their looting, or if the player has looted a lot and they want to take it for themselves. These looters are more cowardly than normal troops and will be likely to flee if wounded. The enemy looters will the piles, stealing potential loot from you for themselves, so you must race to get as much loot as possible, or you can attack them for their loot if youre brave enough. You can also leave them alone, focus on getting as much as you can, and get out by exiting the area and retreating through the red barrier like a normal map. You will keep any loot collected if you retreat this way.{newline}{newline}More enemies will show up over time, equipped with ranged weapons and better armor. They will target the player if the player has loot, so be careful and try not to stay too long or youll be overwhelmed.

Guns played a key part in this period of Japanese history. The designs were imported from the west and mass produced in Japan. Known as Tanegashima guns, they were musket-based matchlocks that proved extremely deadly and were able to penetrate Japanese armor with ease. Shokuho has a wide variety of guns, including pistols, muskets, and even an Ozutsu, a small handheld cannon.{newline}{newline}Guns deal high damage, and are highly accurate with the right skills, but are slow to reload. Gunners are vulnerable to cavalry charges, so keep them protected with melee infantry. If you are having trouble dealing with gun troops, try baiting a volley fire from them at a distance, and quickly close the distance with cavalry to disrupt their reloading.{newline}{newline}Gun wielding troops in the first line of a formation will crouch, so the 2nd line in the formation can fire over them. The player may also fire a gun while crouching. Firing a gun while crouching is more accurate. This happens automatically for troops in formation and works even if there are archer troops in the formation as well.

Due to Japan being made up of several islands, boats are required to travel between them. This can be done at ports. There are dozens of ports around Japan. To travel around Japan, you will need to acquire boats. Ports are where you buy or build boats. Larger boats will require them to be built, which takes time. You can see boats in production in the Naval Management screen, which can be accessed by pressing H or clicking the icon in the bottom left corner of the screen.{newline}{newline}Once you have enough boats to carry your army, you can go on the water by clicking the “Set Sail” button. If you cant afford to buy boats, you can also take a ferry, which will take you to a specific port you choose. The ferry will cost more money depending on how many troops you have in your party, and how much your party is carrying. Finally, ports are where you buy or build boats. Larger boats will require them to be built, which takes time. You can see boats in production in the Naval Management screen.

Naval battles are a custom feature unique to Shokuho. It has been designed from scratch to feel like the naval battles of 16th century Japan.{newline}{newline}Naval battles work in custom battles and in the Campaign. For custom battles, boats are chosen automatically based on the number of troops selected for each side. For campaign battles, there is a custom UI to let the player choose which boats they want to select, and which troops go in what specific ship the player selects.All naval battles happen on the open ocean, with each side starting apart from each other. The player can control their ships with simple commands. Each ship has their own formation. The player can tell a ship to move to a specific point by giving the move order command while selecting that ships formation. They can also tell ships to charge, causing them to sail towards the nearest enemy ship. If you order a ship to target a specific enemy formation, they will sail towards that specific ship. You can also tell a ship to stop by issuing the stop order. All other movement orders have no function in naval battles.{newline}{newline}You can pilot the ship manually by walking up to the pilot position, near the rear of each ship, and using it. You can steer it by using the movement keys.{newline}{newline}Ships can be sunk and lost. A ship can be sunk by taking too much damage, and almost certainly guaranteeing the death of any crew on board. The most common way of a ship sinking is through collision damage. A ship getting repeatedly collided with will cause a lot of damage, and if a ship takes enough damage, it will begin to sink. Guns can also do a large amount of damage to ships. When a ship starts sinking, it will slowly fill up with water until it is below the surface completely. If one of your ships sinks, even if you win the battle, it will be removed from your list of available ships. Losing a naval battle will also force you to lose all the ships brought into the battle.{newline}{newline}Any agent that falls in the water will drown and die. This is accompanied by a custom drowning animation. This is part of why a sinking ship is so deadly for any troops inside.{newline}{newline}Boarding is the main way to fight in naval battles. Two ships can be boarded when they are near each other, not moving, and facing the same parallel direction. Boarding can happen with ships facing opposite direction, or the same direction. Once boarding begins, the ships will slowing start to align next to each other until they line up, then they will strafe towards each other until they collide. Once this happens, boarding begins, and troops on one boat will begin to board the other. The troops who board are decided by whether the player is issuing the charge command on that formation or not. The player can also board by pressing the use key on the side of the ship that is touching the other ship, which will place them on the other ship. Once all the troops on one side are dead, the troops will head back to their ship and positions and sail out again to find another ship to attack{newline}{newline}{newline}{newline}{newline}{newline}.

Duel locations are spread out across Japan. You can enter these locations and initiate a duel with a duelist. These are intended to be more difficult one on one fights, and they also have some cinematics, along with beautiful, handcrafted scenes to set the tone. Winning a duel will give you renown and respect throughout Japan.

Temples are neutral settlements where the player and AI can recruit special temple related troops, buy books from temples which can improve skills, or donate to temples to improve relations. There are several subtypes of temples based on several distinct religions. Donating to a temple improves the relations with that specific temple, along with every temple following that specific religion.

The camp feature lets the player interact with their army in interesting ways. Here you can promote troops to companions, select a book to read, or simply wait and let your army recover. Waiting in a camp recovers health faster than out in the open, but slower than waiting in a settlement.

Books can be bought and read to improve skills. You can select which book to read through the camp feature. Reading a book happens over time naturally. Reading a book while waiting, whether in a settlement or the camp, increases the reading speed. There are dozens of book types, some extremely rare that can even offer focus points to the player.

Troops that perform well in battle can be promoted to companions. After a battle you will receive a notification that a troop or some troops are ready to promote. To promote a troop, enter the camp and select the promote troop option. Here you will see a list of troops available to promote, with their skills on the left side of the screen. Selecting them and hitting the promote button will make them a companion. Hitting the reward button will give all troops of that type an XP boost, but they will no longer be promotable.

The enlistment feature lets you enlist with a lord as a normal troop, much like troops do with the players party. To enlist in a lords party, simply choose the “I wish to enlist in your army” dialogue option. You will follow the lords army and engage in battles they engage in. Overtime you will earn XP and promote to the next unit. You will be given equipment based on your troop, or you can equip your own equipment that you find if you prefer that. When at peace time, your lord may order a mock battle to take place between two sides of the lords party. This is a way for you to gain valuable experience without being at war. Once you reach the noble tier of troops (tier 4), you will start receiving tasks from your lord, where you will be asked to leave the party and complete them. Such tasks include scouting enemy settlements, picking up supplies from towns, engaging enemy parties, or when at peace, dealing with looters. Once you reach the max tier of troop and gain enough XP, it will be possible to become a direct vassal of the clan you are enlisted with, even if your renown is lower than normally possible to become a vassal.

Strategically located in the westernmost part of the Sanyō region, near the Kanmon Straits that separate Honshu from Kyushu, Kusidzaki is a port castle town originally by the Naitō clan, from which it is possible to control the sea and the flow of trade and people across the western provinces.

Positioned near the confluence of several key trade routes in the Chūgoku region, the castle town of Sanbonmacu has become a target for expanding warlords. While its military importance seems negligible, its location along vital supply routes makes it a key target for forces looking to consolidate control over the region.

Originally built as a small fortified residence for the Mōri clan this coastal castle town grew in importance along with the expansion of its inhabitants power, while its hilltop location ensures control over the surrounding territories and sea routes.

Iŭami is famed for its rich silver mines, which have made it one of the most valuable settlements in Japan. The most powerful daimyos of the region have long battled for control of the Iŭami ginzan, which has most recently fallen to the Mōri clan.

Hasantoda is a castle town in Sanin that traces its origins back to the Kamakura period and before that to the Heian period when a fortress was built to protect trade routes and the renowned local steel production. More recently, Hasantoda became the stage for the last stand of the once dominant Amago clan against the ascendant Ōuchi and Mōri clans, with the conquest by Mōri Motonari marking the definitive shift of power in the region.

Okajama is a castle town located in the western part of the Chūgoku region, providing both military and economic advantages through access to maritime trade routes and strategic passage between Honshu and Shikoku

Icidziodani is a fortified town in western Hokuriku, surrounded on all sides by the natural defences of rivers and mountains, making it a difficult target for any besieger. Built by the Asakura clan, Icidziodani has grown into a centre of culture, craftsmanship and religion thanks to the hospitality afforded by the Asakura clan to refugees fleeing Kioto during the Ōnin War, making it a jewel rivaling the Imperial Capital itself.

Originally established as a humble supply post at the edge of fertile plains, Ojama has evolved into a bustling castle town along eastern Japans trade routes and a vital military outpost at the crossroads of the competing Uesugi and Hojo clans.

A Nanao, the stronghold of the Hatakeyama clan, is one of the most important castle towns along the Noto Peninsula. Surrounded by mountains and the sea, its defenses are strong, and its harbor allows for active maritime trade.

Perched atop a steep mountain, the castle town of Kasuhajama was originally a possession of the Nagao clan, but has served as the seat of the powerful Uesugi clan since Uesugi Kenshin, born a Nagao, took over. Kenshin turned Kasuhajama into a center of military power in Echigo from which he departed several times at the head of his armies to challenge the Takeda clan.

Situated on the coast of Echigo Province, Nihata is a prosperous port town benefiting from maritime trade and fertile agricultural lands. The Shinano River provides an essential route for transporting rice and goods inland. The town falls under the influence of Uesugi Kenshin, whose strong rule ensures stability in the region. Fishermen, salt merchants, and shipbuilders contribute to Niigatas economy, making it an important asset for Kenshins war efforts.

Fukasi is a castle town built amongst the mountains of Shinano to protect the domains of the Ogasawara clan until it was taken over by its parent clan following a famous siege by Takeda Shingen, who subsequently converted it into one of the outposts of the expanding Takeda clan.

Kofu, a castle town in the heart of Kai Province in the southern part of the Tōsan region, has been the home of the Takena clan since its beginnings, but has only recently grown considerably thanks to Takeda Shingen, who has made it the centre of his expanding domain and undertaken major flood control projects to increase agricultural production and quality of life

Sunpu has served as the seat of the powerful Imagawa clan for decades, during which the castle town has flourished as a center of governance, trade and culture, benefiting from its location along the strategic Tōkaidō road. However, the Imagawas power has declined significantly since their crushing defeat at the hands of Oda Nobunaga exposing Sunpu and other Imagawa domains to the thirst for conquest of neighbouring lords.

Chamamacu is a castle town in Tokai, built by the Imagawa clan to guard the access the access to the vital Tōkaidō highway, it was then taken over by the rising Tokugawa Ieyasu in the aftermath of the battle of Okehazama.

Okadzaki, the birthplace of the rising lord Tokugawa Ieyasu, is a vital castle town in Mikawa Province. Under Tokugawa rule, it has been reinforced as a military base, securing the clans control over the region. The castle town is flourishing, with a growing population of samurai, merchants, and craftsmen. Its position along the Tōkaidō road makes it an essential stop for travelers and military movements.

Built in the Kamakura period to guard the highways between Kioto and the Shogunal capital, Kijosu has long been the seat of the Oda clan of Owari and the site of political intrigue and military conflicts surrounding the clan, at least until the young lord Oda Nobunaga chose to move his seat to Hifu. Although the relocation of the court weakened its position, Kijosu remains an important fortified city bustling with activity.

“The one who controls Hifu controls Japan” is a common saying that emphasises the strategic location of this castle town. Once a possession of the Saitō clan and recently seized by Oda Nobunaga, who chose to rename it after the legendary mountain where most of ancient china was unified and the birthplace of Confucious, signalling to everyone his intention to unify the whole of Japan.

A Odaŭara, the stronghold of the powerful Hojo clan, stands as an impregnable fortress in the Kanto region. With its vast network of walls, moats, and outlying fortifications, it is considered one of the most well-defended castles in Japan. The city below is a thriving center of trade, with merchants, farmers, and artisans benefiting from Hojo governance. Odawaras strategic location allows the Hojo to control access to eastern Japan, ensuring their dominance over the region.

Originally developed from a small fishing village as a fortified residence for a local noble of the Heian Period, Edo was later fortified to become the castle town that currently towers over the Musashino Plateau and Edo Bay. The recent turmoil in Kantō has seen Edo shift between the different warring Clans and has severely hampered its development, but the city still retains its enormous potential.

Originally the seat of the namesake clan, Ota is a castle town in Kantō in close proximity to the vital Tōkaidō road, which connects the region to the capital Kioto, making it an important military and administrative center.

First built in the Heian period, the castle town of Ucunomija was the seat of the clan of the same name for centuries and one of the most important centres in the Kantō region which exerts control over many of the local land routes.

Built as the fortified residence of the Nagano clan, the castle town of Minoŭa has long been a critical stronghold for the control of the surrounding region, which made it a mandatory target in the confrontation between the Uesugi and Takeda clans, until the forces of Takeda Shingen seized Minoŭa resulting in the demise of the Nagano clan and the death of all its members.

Chimedzi was originally built in the early Muromachi period by the Akamatsu clan as a small fortified outpost atop Himeyama Hill and along the western route to capital Kioto, but underwent several demolitions and reconstructions until it reached its present form as a mighty castle town barring the way to would-be invaders.

Dominated by the temple fortress of Ishiyama Hongan-ji, Osaka has grown into a major center of religious and economic activity. The temple fortress, controlled by the militant Ikkō-ikki, serves as the stronghold of the Jōdo Shinshū sect, resisting the rule of samurai warlords.

Sakaj, one of the wealthiest and most autonomous cities in Japan, thrives as a center of commerce. The citys merchant guilds operate independently of the warring daimyōs, maintaining direct trade with China and Portuguese traders. Famous for its high-quality firearms, swords, and luxury goods, Sakais economy flourishes even as war ravages the surrounding regions.

Once the great imperial capital of Japan, Nara remains a center of Buddhist influence and cultural heritage. The massive temples of Tōdaiji and Kōfukuji stand as reminders of its former glory, housing powerful monastic factions.

Kioto, once the unrivaled capital of Japan, emerged almost completely destroyed by the struggles for control over the central power. The authority of the Ashikaga Shogunate has crumbled, leaving the city at the mercy of the warring daimyos, while the Imperial Court sits back and watches helplessly. Nevertheless, Kioto remains the depository of secular traditions and while its days as the true centre of power seem to be over, its religious and cultural influence persists.

A seemingly quiet castle town built atop Mount Kinugasa, Kanondzi has been repeatedly embroiled in the conflicts of its ancestral owners, the Rokkaku clan, and only the castles natural defenses have allowed it to resist several sieges.

Built as the fortified seat of the Azai clan to rule over the surrounding region, the castle town of Odani sits atop a steep ridge, its defenses making it a formidable stronghold, while its position along key trade routes ensure the growing prosperity of the settlement.
Kojama is strategic stronghold in Southern Kyushu, nestled in the rugged terrain of Higo Province, where mountain passes connect inland domains to the western coast.

A small but strategically located settlement, Uci serves as a waypoint for travelers and merchants moving through its province. The towns location makes it valuable to any daimyo seeking control over the surrounding region.

The castle town of Sadoŭara, located in the southern portion of Kyushu, has served as the seat of the Itō clan for generations. Benefiting from fertile plains and proximity to maritime routes, Sadoŭara has flourished as both an administrative and agricultural center becoming the epicenter of the Itō clans expansion attempts in the region.

A castle town nestled deep in the mountains of South-western Kyushu, Hitoyoshi has served as the seat of the Sagara clan since the Kamakura period. It is said that during the construction work a moon-shaped stone was unearthed, thus giving rise to the alternative folk name of moon castle. Popular tales aside, Hitoyoshi stands as an imposing fortification that has only once been attacked by an enemy and with a fatal outcome.

Benefiting from its position along key maritime trade routes and its proximity to the islands northern provinces, Niusima has grown into a prosperous castle town, also thanks to the influence of the Ōtomo clan, that has promoted the town as a center of local governance.

Kiidani is a fortified town in the southernmost part of the Kinki region, protected more by geography than by its walls, with its isolated location making it largely untouched by surrounding conflicts so far.

Located in north-western Kyushu, Yanagawa is strategically located on the banks of the Chikugo River, at the crossroads of trade routes connecting much of the region, which facilitates both trade and military movements.

Well-positioned between coastal trade routes and mountain strongholds of western Kyushu, Kumamato has enjoyed steady growth thanks to the flow of trade and local production that made it a thriving and well-defended castle town.

Perched on a prominent hill in northern Kyushu, Tachibanayama was originally built for its namesake Tachibana clan as a fortified town, whose control over the surrounding areas remains vital for securing key trade routes and access to both land and sea.

Muranaka has long served as a local stronghold in Western Kyushu, functioning as a minor seat of governance under the protection of the Aso clan, whose authority once extended across the central highlands. With the Aso clans power sharply declined under pressure from the Shimazu to the south and the Ōtomo to the east, Muranaka is now left vulnerable.

The castle town of Chinoe sits on the west coast of Kyushu on the Shimabara Peninsula. Built in the early Kamakura period, Chinoe has since served as the home base and major source of profits for the Aryma clan, who from here controlled maritime trade routes and more recently the Nanban foreign trade.
Nakamura, is a castle town in Western Shikoku. Surrounded by rivers and mountains, it enjoys a natural defensive advantage, benefitting from the fertile lands that produce rice and timber.
Located in the inland reaches of Shikoku, Kurose is a strategically placed castle town that provides control over the inland routes and a valuable defensive position against neighbouring domains.

Judzuki is a fortified port town in western Shikoku, built by the Kōno clan as as a gateway to maritime commerce. Despite its modest size, Judzuki has prospered thanks to the Kōno clans unofficial alliance with local pirates and the castles defensive position.

Akoŭ is a castle town located in a a key strategic location in the southern part of Shikoku, that has been serving as the ancestral seat of the Chōsokabe clan since the Kamakura period. Akoŭ recently played a crucial role in the consolidation of power by Chōsokabe Motochika.

Amahiry is a fortified town on top of the namesake Mountain, built by the Kagawa Clan as its seat in the Northern part of Shikoku. Thanks to its strategically fortified location and access to the Inland Sea coast, Amahiry is an important centre for controlling the surrounding territory and trade routes.

Usiki is a castle town in eastern Kyushu built by the Daimyo Ōtomo Sōrin as the main base for his expanding domain. Located on what is virtually an island connected to the rest of Kyushu only during low tides, Usiki dominates the eponymous bay.

The castle town of Kurokawa was built by the Ashina clan as its seat in the southernmost part of Ōu region, an isolated area that ensured that Kurokawa could grow while avoiding the worst of the conflicts between neighbouring lords.

Built during the Kamakura period, the castle town of Yonezawa has served as the seat of the Date clan since they drove out the previous lords and from here they plan the domination of neighbouring domains.

Yamagata has been the seat of the Mogami since before they adopted this name, its location marked by the many mountains and rivers that shield it and at the same time make it an important connection centre for the surrounding regions.

Isinomaki is a bustling coastal town in the southern part of the Ōu region that has grown as an important port for trade and fishing as Matsushima Bay provides natural protection and the Kitakami River serves as a vital route for transporting goods inland. Although its strategic location has ensured its prosperity, it also makes it an important military target for the plans of expansion of the local clans.

Sakata is a a key port in the northern part of the Tōhoku region, the castle town has grown into a vital hub for trade, particularly due to its access to the Sea of Japan and its proximity to the rich agricultural lands of the surrounding region.

Strategically positioned on the coast of the Noto Peninsula, Tsuchizaki-Minato has long served as a crucial point for maritime trade and the transport of goods between the main islands and the northern provinces.
Located along a key mountain pass, Sannohoe is a fortified town that serves as a military outpost, guarding vital routes for trade and troop movements on the borders of competing powers.

Located in the northernmost reaches of Honshu, Tasaminato serves as a key trade hub with the Ainu people of Hokkaido although the harsh winters and isolation make it difficult to defend, leaving it vulnerable to raids. Once a thriving port and administrative center of the Andō clan, Tasaminato has declined following the clans expulsion.
This is the retirement retreat location.
The Hokkoku Bune is a very large, slow moving transport vessel, designed to move an enourmous amount of cargo, but is vulnerable in combat.
The Kobaya Bune is a small, fast moving ship designed for skirmishing and reconnaissance.
The Seki Bune is a medium sized troop transport vessel, designed for transporting troops across the seas. It can hold its own in a direct naval engagement.
Siege Braziers and additional material allow archers to light their arrows on fire
Naval Cannons are rare, and take time to set up, but are devistating to fortifications
Tate shields provide defenses for ranged units
Ammunition Cache provides a resuply point for archers and gunners
Rice is taken and brewed into sake. Few things keeps the common folk and troops as happy as sake.
We ferment soybeans into miso and soy sauce. Everyone loves soy!
Perilla or whale oil are converted into smooth oil in the press. Oil is used to light lamps, for soap, and for many other purposes.
We work wood and ramie into fine bows and arrows.
We make candles out of whale fat or lacquer.
We specialize in the creation of tools, used in other professions.
Armorsmithies are fundamental for militaries, producing protective armor for troops.
Weaponsmithies are fundamental for militaries, producing melee weaponry for troops.
Rare precious metals are turned into valuable jewelery by jewelers. Jewelery is the finest of all trade goods.
We form the raw fibers of ramie into a usable cloth.
We form the raw fibers of cotton into a usable cloth.
We weave raw silk into usable material to create the most luxurious clothing.
We create Tanegashima guns using iron, wood, and sulfur.

One of the dominant clans in Kyushu, the Otomo lay claim to swathes of the hilly eastern side of the island. Flourishing port cities along the coast have introduced Christianity and trade to the Otomo lands. Thanks to this cooperation with Europe, the Otomo clan have gained an upper hand in Japans technological arms race by bolstering their ranks with imported matchlock weapons. With land reaching from Bungo in the south to Hakata in the north the realm of the Otomo is not without contention. The Mory clan have come from Honshu taking Moji castle and now threatening Otomo control of the vital port city of Hakata. With a Mory foothold now in Kyushu and with Ryūzōji power rising in the west, the Otomo must rally under clan daimyo Otomo Sorin or risk losing vital land and ports.
The Yamakuguri-shu are a mercenary company of mountain priests originating from Mount Kinpo. They act as shinobi to investigate and spy on enemies, and are a competent fighting force.
The Shiwaku-shu are a mercenary company consisting of mainly transport vessels. They have served many clans in their logistical efforts, but are not known for their military prowess.

The Tango-Kaizoku are a mercenary company of pirates with a stronghold in the Tango province. They are one of the biggest pirate factions and boast a fleet of hundreds of ships. Their numbers are something to be feared.

The Saika-shu are a mercenary company consisting of teppo troops and jizamurai. They were quick to adopt the use of matchlocks and prove their effectiveness. Now they are known for their accurate and deadly use of guns.

The Hakusan-shuto are a mercenary company of warrior monks. They worked closely with the Asakura clan and much of their strength is thanks to them. They come from the Hakusan Cheisendzi temple, and are a formidable group of warriors.

The Katsurayama-shu are a mercenary company of former samurai turned monk. They are based on the mountains of Togakushi and Iizuna. They are known for their knowledge of mountain terrain and gun usage.
The Suruga-shu are a mercenary company focused on naval warfare. They are known for logisitcal support in the southern Chubu region.
The Kazama-shu are a mercenary company focused on espionage and reconnaissance. They have a bad reputation due to their looting and theft, but are effective in combat.
The Kurohabaki-shu are a mercenary company focused on espionage and sabotage. They are known for their unconvential and disruptive tactics.

Saikaidō, meaning West Sea Circuit, is the westernmost region of Japan, comprising the island of Kyushu. Far from the power struggles for control of the shogunate in the capital and closer to the Asian mainland, the region has grown into a maritime and trade center, with goods and new ideas being brought by Chinese and Korean traders and most recently by newly come nanban foreigners. Although the Saikai people have a long tradition of sea commerce with other countries, they are no strangers to warfare either, as daimyo battle for control of the islands while swarms of pirates harass the profitable trade routes for plunder.
